caption_text: lIT K1 Fig 6 Arrhenius diagram for first order overall disappearance of propane Kinetics of coke deposition in the thermal cracking of propane 639 different reactors is remarkable In addition, it is a reli- able basis for the scale-up to be illustrated in the last section of this paper 7 KINETICS 0F COKING A representative curve of coke vs time and a coking rate vs time curve determined by the electrobalance technique is shown in Fig 7 lt shows that the coking rate is high in the beginning, but tends to an asymptotic value This indicates that imtially surface reactions are taking place, which decline after a certain time Initially the coke formation is catalyzed by the metal surface, but once the tatter is completely covered a steady state activity is achieved, probably as a result from the mter- action between gas phase components and already deposited coke precursors The cokmg is therefore considered to be of a heterogeneous nature A similar phenomenon has been observed recently by Shah et al [7] for n-octane cracking It can be seen that this asymptotic rate is reached very rapidly, usually within an hour The asymptotic coking rate as a function of conversion is shown in Fig 8 The coke yield is ex- tremely small when compared to that of other products 0 142 wt% in the asymptotic range, at 69% propane con- version and 870 C Coke may be formed by a parallel mechanism or by a series mechanism or by both, m analogy to coking m catalytic reactions as shown by Froment and Bischoff [8] and as was recently reviewed by Froment[16] In pyrolysis, the mechanism is highly complicated due to the large number of radical reactions Only the simplified models shown in Table I were investigated For the parallel mechanism of model I CM€ * products k2 C3!!5 + coke the coking rate equation may be written I l x Pt r,, = k2Cci~ = k2 (.1 + o + (6) gm2hFi X=406 / T 828 c g ni2 hi1 Fig 7 Rate of coke formation and coke conient on cylmder as a function of time 6=lmoI N2/mS c3118 o r 40 C 20 40 60 80 CONVERSION /. Fig 8 Asymptotic coking rate vs propane conversion 640 K M SuI4akP.xs and G F FROMENT Table 1 Coking mechamsms Parallel mechanism Model I k1 i C3H5 / products 2 C3H5 a coke Consecutive mechanisms Model II 1 C3H5 products 3 C~H6 ~-~coke Model III il I C3Hs * products 4 C~}L~~~t* coke Model IV C3H5 . products 63 5 C~H6 / coke 66 6 C2H4 * coke The estimated parameters of the models are shown in Table 2 Model IV with both propylene and ethylene as intermediates was discarded due to non significantly determined parameters Since the activation energy for the coking reaction is very high for the parallel mechanism, Model I is not plausible The parameters of Model II and III with respectively propylene or ethylene as coke precursors are positive and highly significant Discrimination between these models was not possible by statistical tests However, a preference to Model II was given since the residual sum of squares of reaction rates was smaller for Model II than Model III This was substantiated by experiments with mixed feeds The asymptotic coking rates measured with feeds containing 80 mole% of propane and 20 mole% of ethylene or pro- pylene are compared in Fig 9 with those obtained with pure propane This also favours qualitatively the conclusion that Model II is supenor to Model III, but the discrimination based on statistical tests failed Further, coke is one of the major products in propylene cracking [17] The best parameters for Model II were obtained by considering all the data for pure and mixed feeds They are also shown in Table 2 where r,, is the coking rate per unit area r,, is obtained experimentally from the coke deposited on the cylinder, which has a known surface area The frequency factor and the activation energy obtained are shown in Table 2 For the series mechanism of Model II, the rate expression for the coking reaction is I x Yc3n~ r,, =k3Cc)Hi=k3 1(l 8+ ~ (7) Estimation of rate coefficients is extremely simple in the case of a completely mixed reactor when compared to the case of a tubular reactor For example, if the above series reaction is studied in a tubular reactor, k, and k3 have to be simultaneously determined, which requires the integration of the continuity equations for all the species However, in a completely mixed reactor, measuring the rate of coking and the outlet concentration of propylene, which is also the concentration in the reactor, allows k3 to be determined from eqn (7) only Similar series mechanisms with ethylene as inter- mediate (Model HI) and with both propylene and ethy- lene as intermediates (Model IV) were also tested 8 COKE PROFILES IN AN INDUSTRIAL REACTOR The simulation of an industrial reactor requires the integration of the continuity equations for each species, Table 2 Parameter estimates for various coking models Reaction Rate coefficient Frequency factor [g coke/(mole i/I m1 secjl t value Activation energy [kcal/molej t value I k, 451x10 t 150 4928 143 2 k2 Characteristics of an indu stnal r eactor for propane cracking Length = 95m Diameter = O 108m Radiusofthebend = 0178m Length of the bend = O 553m Thickness of the wall = 0008m Inlet temperature = 600 C Inlet pressure (clean) = 3 0 atm abs Outlet pressure (clean) = 2 0 atm abs Propane flow rate 4599 kmolesfhr Dilution factor = 0406 kg steam/kg propane Density of the coke = I 6 kgfl Thermal conductivity of the coke 000154 kcall(m sec K) Kinetics of coke deposition in the thermal cracking of propane 641 of the energy equation and of the pressure drop equa for the bends, where and tion ~= (O7+~xO35)~ ~ =005l+0 19f- dF, lTd,2 -a-- -(~ s,,r,)--~ (8) (9) dT I ~ [Q(z)lTdt +2L~i~~r,(_AH),] d 1 fIdT dp, ~(lIMm)+~~y~+Fr 1 Pr M,,,p, acG2RT where j represents the species, i reaction number, s,j the stoichiometric coefficients For propane cracking, the present authors [18] have already proposed a molecular reaction scheme based on an investigation in a pilot cracker The same reaction scheme, shown in Table 3, is adopted here The characteristics of the industrial reac- tor are given in Table 4 The friction factors were computed from Fr=0092Re 2/d, for the straight portion of the tubes and from Fr =0092 Re 2/d, + ~/l7Rb The angle of the bend A is 180 in the present case The heat capacities were calculated by a third degree polynomial m temperature with the coefficients obtained by Thinh et ai [19] from recent experimental data The viscosity of the mixture was calculated by Sutherland s method[20] Under clean tube conditions a continuous heat flux profile along the reactor shown m Fig 10 was used With this profile an outlet conversion of 90% was obtained, a value which can be compared with the experimental value of 90 7% The simulated gas temperature, conversion and pressure profiles under clean tube conditions are also shown in Fig 10, along with the mdustnal values Excellent agreement was found between the calculated and industrial product dis- tributions, too The coke deposition alters both the inner tube diameter and the heat transfer To account for this requires the local values which are also time dependent Therefore, a suitable coking rate equation has to be Table 3 Reaction scheme for propane cracking 642 K M SUNDAIOAM and G F FROMENT Fig 10 Conversion, heat flux, gas temperature and pressure profiles for industrial cracking of propane under clean tube conditions Lines, simulated, points, industnal values oc,, ~ = r,, I. REDUCTION IN DIAMETER l2t~/dt 100) REACTOR LENOTH, m coupled with (8), (9) and (10) Since the coking is considered to involve intermediate polymenc species deposited on the wall its rate is taken at the internal tube skin temperature Model II with propylene as intermediate was adopted for r Since the rate of coke deposition is low, quasi steady state condi- tions may be assumed Consequently, only the coke thickness is a function of time, while the continuity equations, the energy equation and the pressure drop equation do not contain any explicit time dependence The tube diameter d~ was updated penodically, however The increase in coke thickness tat,, in the time interval /it m the reactor between z and L~z for, e g for the heterogeneous case is given by ~ _Aexp( E/R?)~t p,, X 106 where ~ is the average concentration of propylene, T is the average coke surface temperature between z and z + Az and p,, is the density of the coke in kg/i The updated diameter between z and z + Az becomes d0 ~w = d~ old 2At,, A step by step application of the above formula yields the coke thickness along the reactor at any instant When the coking is accounted for, a certain policy for the operation of the reactor has to be selected Since the heat flux evolution with time is not known, the gas temperature profile under clean tube conditions is retained for all times The outlet pressure was held constant To achieve this and to maintain the flow rate, the inlet pressure has to be increased as time progresses This leads to a two point boundary value problem Local coke values after 100, 300 and 700 hr are shown in Fig 11 The reaction between coke and steam was not accounted for it is known from industrial practice to be negligible under normal operating conditions As a check this reaction was included in the reaction model, with the rate parameters obtained by Riede and Hanesian[21} This reduced the coke thickness after 700 hr by less than 001cm It is clear from Fig 11 that there is a profile m the coke 20 10 700 hr 100 5b ~io - REACTOR LENGTH/. Fig il Coke profiles in an industnal reactor, Model H for coking Kinetics of coke deposition m the thermal cracking of propane 643 thickness The highest amount of coke is formed at the exit of the reactor, where the surface temperature is highest At this spot the tube diameter is reduced by 18 4% after 700 hr of operation The coke layer thickness is 098 cm The coke layer thicknesses obtained from the simulation are in agreement with observations made in industnal cracking coils It was found that, when the expenmental coking rates were expressed per umt reac- tor volume, rather than per umt metal surface, the amount of coke predicted by the simulation at the gas phase temperature, was far too high when compared with industrial observations The evolution with time of the maximum tube skin temperature (at the exit), of the mlet pressure and of the exit conversion are shown in Fig 12 The exit converston drops because of the reduction in space time, although the inlet pressure increases The evolution of temperature proffles are shown in Fig 13 The average rate of increase in the maximum tube skin temperature is 1 75 C per day Chambers and Potter[22] quote a value of 2 3 C per day for indu stnal operations, but the feed stock is not mentioned Even higher values would be obtained if the inlet pressure were further raised, so as to maintain the exit conversion constant The temperature difference between the tube skin and the gas at the exit amounts to 50 C at the start, but reaches 100 C after 700 hr The evolution of external tube skin temperature substantiates the conclusion of Mol [23] who reported that with naphtha cracking coils with an internal diameter exceeding 7 5 cm the run length is hmited by the tube skin temperature The simulations also clearly show that the temperature has a stronger influence on the location of the maximum coke thickness than the propylene yield Acknowledgement The authors acknowledge the support of the Process Data Group of K T I Zoetermeer, The Netherlands T~.

table_reason: Table 4 is introduced in S0, and S1-S2 provide descriptive details about the table content, including reactor characteristics and coke profiles, forming a complete caption.
